blocks.text: In like manner it could be shown that $\Gamma(n) = (n-1)!$. And if $n$ is an integer it will be seen that we finally reduce to $\Gamma(1) = 0$, the value of which is $1$.

Thus the last result will not hold, however, if $n$ is not an integer, but the general method of attack holds good; and tables may be consulted for defining the values of $\Gamma(n)$ for many values of $n$, whether $n$ be an integer or not. Thus if an integral can be reduced to a Gamma function or a combination of Gamma functions, its numerical evaluation may be effectively be performed as in the last example.
